title: The Camp on the North Side

content:
We now come to the final arrangement of the camp. After the east, south, and west sides, the last division stood on the **north side** of the Tabernacle. On this side were **Dan, Asher, and Naphtali**, with **Dan leading** this group. The total number of men able to go to war on Dan’s side was **157,600** (Numbers 2:25-31). When Israel moved through the wilderness, this division marched **last**, under their banners.

In summary, all twelve tribes together counted **603,550** fighting men (Numbers 1:46). Yet as we have seen before, the Levites were not included in this military number because they were set apart for service. So now, with the north side, the camp structure is complete. God arranged His people in perfect order; east, south, west, and north, around His dwelling place. This shows again that God is a God of order, not confusion (1 Corinthians 14:33).

Let us first look at the meanings of the names on the north side. **Dan** means *“Judge”* or *“He has judged.”* **Asher** means *“Happy”* or *“Blessed.”* **Naphtali** means *“My wrestling”* or *“My struggle.”* These three names together form a deep message: judgment, blessing, and struggle. When God places these names on the north side, He is teaching us something about the final stage of the journey.

In the Bible, the **north** carries strong meaning. Many prophetic passages connect the north with judgment. In Jeremiah 1:14-15, God says, “Out of the north an evil shall break forth upon all the inhabitants of the land.” Again in Jeremiah 4:6, He says, “I will bring evil from the north, and a great destruction.” The north becomes a direction from which correction and discipline come.

At the same time, the north is also connected with glory and kingship. Psalm 48:2 says, “Mount Zion… on the sides of the north, the city of the great King.” So the north carries two themes: **judgment and the city of the King**. It is not only destruction; it is also restoration and rulership. Even Isaiah 14:13 shows that Satan wanted to ascend to “the sides of the north,” showing that the north is symbolically connected with authority and divine throne imagery.

In Job 37:22, Elihu says, “Fair weather comes out of the north: with God is terrible majesty.” Some translations say “golden splendor comes from the north.” Immediately after this, in Job 38:1, God speaks out of the whirlwind. So the north is also a place from which divine glory appears. It is where judgment and revelation meet.

Now let us bring this into our spiritual lesson. God places Dan, meaning *judge*, at the front of the north camp. This reminds us that judgment begins in the house of God. Scripture says, “For the time is come that judgment must begin at the house of God” (1 Peter 4:17). God corrects His own people first. This is not rejection; it is love. Hebrews 12:6 says, “For whom Yahweh loveth he chasteneth.” When God judges His people, it is fatherly discipline.

Then comes **Asher**, meaning blessed or happy. This teaches us something very important. Even when we are corrected by God, we are not abandoned. James 1:12 says, “Blessed is the man that endureth temptation: for when he is tried, he shall receive the crown of life.” Discipline may feel painful, but it leads to blessing. When we accept correction with humility, it produces righteousness and peace (Hebrews 12:11). So Asher reminds us that true happiness is found in walking rightly with God, even after correction.

Then comes **Naphtali**, meaning wrestling or struggle. This shows that the journey of faith is not without conflict. Jacob wrestled with the angel and would not let go until he received a blessing (Genesis 32:24-28). In the same way, believers wrestle; not against flesh and blood, but against spiritual forces (Ephesians 6:12). Struggle does not mean failure. It means engagement. It means holding on to God through difficulty.

So the north side gives us a full picture. If we go against God and continue in sin, judgment will come. But if we accept His correction, we are blessed. And even in struggle, if we remain faithful, God reveals Himself to us. Just as God spoke to Job out of the whirlwind after great suffering, He will speak to those who endure.

There is also a beautiful natural picture. In the far north of the earth, near the North Pole, we see the **northern lights**; auroras that shine in the darkness. At the North Pole, there are six months of daylight and six months of darkness. This unique light cycle is unlike most of the planet. Though this is geography, it gives us a reflection. Even in the darkest seasons, light can break through. God’s glory shines in unexpected places.

Spiritually, the north reminds us that beyond judgment and struggle lies the **city of the Great King**. Psalm 48:2 speaks of Zion on the sides of the north. Revelation speaks of the New Jerusalem, where God dwells with His people. After correction, endurance, and wrestling, comes establishment in the Kingdom. This is the visible reign of Christ.

Christ Himself walked this path. He endured judgment; not for His sin, but for ours. He suffered and wrestled in Gethsemane. He endured the cross. Yet through that struggle came blessing and glory. He is now exalted and is a Judge and King (Acts 17:31). His Peaceable Kingdom will be established, and righteousness will dwell there.

So for us, the lesson is clear. When we face discipline, let us not run away from God. Let us remember Dan; He has judged. Let us remember Asher; blessed is the one who endures. Let us remember Naphtali; struggle is part of the journey. If we continue to walk in His ways, God will bring us to the city of the Great King. Judgment refines. Blessing strengthens. Wrestling prepares.

The north side is not the end of hope. It is the final refining before glory.
When God finishes His work in His people, they will shine in His Kingdom. And the One who judges is also the One who saves. Let us therefore walk carefully, humbly, and faithfully, until we stand in the presence of the King.

title: Prayer
text:
Father Yahweh, when Your judgment comes to correct us, help us to receive it with humility and trust.
In our struggles and wrestling, give us strength to hold on to You and never let go. Teach us to see Your blessing even in discipline, knowing You are shaping us for glory. Let Your light shine over us in our darkest seasons, and speak to us as You spoke to Job. Lead us safely to the city of the Great King, where we will stand in Your presence forever. Amen.
